title: Tyrone Mings reveals racist chanting started pre-match but insists abuse did not ruin England debut
text:
Tyrone Mings has revealed that he first heard racist chanting from Bulgaria supporters during the warm-up before England’s Euro 2020 qualifying victory in Sofia.

But Mings, who was one of the first England players to report racism to the linesman, insisted the chanting did not ruin his international debut and claimed he felt sorry for those responsible.

England’s 6-0 thrashing of Bulgaria was stopped twice because of racism and Aston Villa star Mings told a linesman “eh, did you hear that?” before the first stoppage.

“I heard it before I even got to the other side of the pitch for the warm up,” said Mings. “We then spoke about it when we came in after the warm up and, obviously, I don’t need to spell it out. I think everybody heard the chants, but we stood together and we made certain decisions.”

Manager Gareth Southgate and his squad discussed whether or not to stay on the pitch during the second stoppage just before half-time and spoke about the issue again at the break before going out for the second half. They had agreed to go off if there were more incidents, but Mings did not hear any more racist chanting during the second period.
